doc.title: TeXML: an XML vocabulary for TeX
doc.p: TeXML is an XML vocabulary for TeX. A processor translates TeXML source into TeX.

table.caption: Example of TeXML to TeX translation

doc.p: One of the main benefits of TeXML usage is an automatical translation of the TeX special symbols.

table.caption: Example of translation of special TeX symbols

doc.p: The TeXML processor supports different output encodings and escapes out-of-encoding chars automatically.

table.caption: Example of translation of non-ASCII characters

doc.p: There is a TeXML specification. DTD is included into the distribution.

Rationalities and objectives of TeXML were presented by Douglas Lovell at the Tex Users Group meeting in 1999. His paper is available online on TUG site: “TeXML: Typesetting XML with TeX” (PDF, 180 Kb).
There was TeXMLatté, a Java implementation of TeXML by IBM alphaWorks, but now this realization “has been retired”. There is also TeXMLapis by Chris Houser, a Perl implementation of TeXML.

sect.title: Getting TeXML
sect.p: The TeXML processor is a Python script. You need Python 2.3 run the script. Additional modules are not required.

You can download Python TeXML in the SourceForge project download area. A distribution archive with extension .tar.gz is a package for Unix and with .zip is for Windows. The only difference between them is in line endings (Unix or DOS style).
Current version is 0.95 beta. Although it is marked as beta, bugs are not expected and the processor should work well.
The software is released under the GNU Public License.
Support is available through the SourceForge project area (TeXML is a part of the GetFO project).
